response.answer_text: It is impossible to stop climate change. What we can do is slow it down significantly. Perhaps in the future, we’ll determine a way to begin reversing the temperature increase and decrease the amount of CO2 in the atmosphere. Every little thing helps, such as reducing or eliminating the amount of plastic you use, recycling if you can, volunteering to reforest or clean up a lake, etc. The best thing you can do is join or start a group with at least one person well versed in climate change and get the information out to the public. While it is getting more press these days, it still isn’t obvious to a large number of people that we are responsible for most of it. At this point, climate change is speeding up due to nations increasing their fossil fuel consumption and production, rather than lowering it as agreed to. Unless we can get our leaders to take climate change seriously, there isn’t a lot the private people can do. Most companies like solar installers or makers and wind turbine builders and installers are needed. Substitutes for plastic are sorely needed, since our entire infrastructure depends on it. Plastic comes from oil. That includes this like PVC piping. We use plastic everywhere; hospital equipment, for instance. We absolutely must get to net zero carbon yesterday. Contrary to what everyone is told, we don’t have until 2030 or 2050 to stop polluting the atmosphere, the ocean, drinking water and the land. If we don’t immediately start major changes, we will not stop the rapidly increasing temperatures, storms, fire, etc. There are things we can do at the same time, in the hope that we can get the Federal government to stop subsidizing oil and gas and begin fining those industries instead. Planting trees and ground cover are one way. Getting state and local government to stop building new houses is another, as is preserving more land. The ocean can only hold so much carbon before it too, starts dying. There are many other, opportunities, too numerous to describe here. My master’s thesis is focused on reversing desertification, which is similar to reforesting, but it instead returning land that has been turned into man made desert into healthy land. It is a much slower and more difficult process than simply reforesting, but reducing the deserts also helps decrease temperatures. I hope to do that professionally once I finish. Do what you can, but most of all, push your governmental bodies to make changes to save water, trees, and land. Put back marshes. Learn more and teach more. Okay, I’ll stop there. I know it’s a little long, but hopefully it will give you some ideas.

R&D. The tools that currently exist to reduce GHG emissions are either too small or too expensive. Several of those are mentioned in other answers here. Because carbon dioxide is so stable in the atmosphere, the only long term answer is to reduce net additions to near zero. This is impractical with current technology. Take solar as an example. One answer below says solar is as cheap as fossil fuels. This is a common misunderstanding. In a sunny location, when solar is a very small contributor, the levelized cost of solar power may be very competitive with natural gas. As solar becomes a more significant source, that changes, because of solar’s intermittency. No sunshine, no power, nighttime being the simplest illustration. All of the conventional power capacity is still needed to carry the entire load between sunset and sunrise. (Wind? It might not be blowing that night.) That means overcapacity. The system has all of the conventional capacity it needs to meet the demand, then solar is added. Overcapacity = excess capital cost = rising utility charges. Germany and Denmark have demonstrated this effect to a very painful degree, and their solar and wind contributions to total electrical output are still below 30%. This technology is just unready to perform the role in which so many have cast it. Or planting trees. It works exactly as described, sucking CO2 out of the atmosphere. If the wood becomes houses, the carbon will stay sequestered for many decades. Beautiful, but the scale is all wrong. While fossil fuels are burned at the current rate, offsetting the carbon emissions by planting trees would take most of the arable land of the world. These are examples of trying to do a job without having adequate tools. The existing technology cannot sharply limit net emissions except at prohibitive expense (with one possible exception noted below). New technology can change that. For example, low cost grid scale storage would allow pv farms to produce and store excess power during the day for use at night. But lithium ion batteries are not low cost and never will be. Research into viable technologies is ongoing, but a commercial solution will require decades (as with almost all important technologies—think about vaccines, cars, airplanes, semiconductors, computing, television, etc.—none of these appeared overnight). Or trees. Enhanced photosynthesis and other genetic modifications may greatly accelerate growth and reduce the land needed. Again, decades away. These are good ideas, they will just take time. Subsidizing and mandating “solutions” is putting the cart before the horse. The priority should be inventing the solutions that won’t need the subsidies and the mandates. Billions of dollars of R&D now will save hundreds of billions in subsidies and excess costs later. A possible exception would be GenIV nuclear power. This may be ready for primetime if implemented in a systematic, modular manner. Many answers by Vincent Maldia on this site provide excellent information. However, this possibility will not be explored in America, where the regulatory environment and public opinion are far too toxic to permit an economical and speedy roll-out. China may be in the process of testing this approach—an advantage of an autocratic government that need not follow rules of law or respect public opinion.

The current direction of climate change is toward an increase in the total thermal energy content of the oceans, continents, and atmosphere. RE: “How can we slow climate change?” The ongoing processes that cause natural climate change are slow. They are things like the movement of tectonic plates, the variations in the orbit of the Earth around the Sun, and biologic changes to the chemistry of the atmosphere. The biologic changes include the gradual conversion almost all of the original carbon dioxide to free oxygen (O2) molecules, oxide minerals, and hydrocarbons over billions of years. Saying that our current concern about climate change is about these exceedingly slow processes is a diversion from the serious problem of the rapid changes occurring now.  The current measured concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere is much higher than it has been for 800,000 years. The consequences of continuing this rate of increase are debatable but it is foolish to expect them all to be harmless. So, the answer to your question is reducing the rate of increase of CO2 in the atmosphere (and oceans). To figure out how to do that, we need to know where the increase is coming from. We know that it is from the oxidizing of fossil fuels because the amount of carbon 14 in the fossil fuels is zero and the ratio of carbon 14 to carbon 12 in the atmosphere has gone down. More specifically, the answer to your question is reducing the amount of fossil fuels that are oxidized and released to the atmosphere. There are many ways to do this. Choosing which of these methods to put into practice should be based on the basis of the largest amount of carbon emission reductions for the money - which is not necessarily the same as the ones that get the most government subsidies and mandates. There is only one currently available energy sources that can replace fossil fuels on a scale large enough to significantly slow global warming - fission nuclear power plants. If we had continued to build fission nuclear power plants at the rate we did in the early 1970’s, global warming would not even be a problem today.

First, realise that it isn’t all about climate change. A particular misunderstanding is that the CO2 issue is that it is not about how much CO2 we pump into the atmosphere. It is about how much carbon we release into the environment as a whole. We can pump as much CO2 as we like, so long as the carbon involved comes from elsewhere in the biological environment. The ‘killer’ is where we take carbon stored in long term (mostly geological) reservoirs (such as coal, oil and gas) and put it into the environment. Also includes things like methane trapped long-term in frozen tundra, and in deposits in river deltas. Emitting CO2 by burning fossil fuels is just an easy way of getting carbon from geological reservoirs into the environment. So, here are my personal suggestions to answer the OP. Our economies currently reward doing things with less human effort, more shareholder return and doesn’t care about resource usage so long as it is cheap. The balance needs to shift to reward doing things with less resources as a priority! I’m not an economist so I’ve no idea how to do this, but I think it is essential. It also doesn’t automatically have to mean ‘more human effort’. But it does have to provide a means of dignified living for all, regardless of their circumstances.push hard to stop exploration for new fossil fuel resources of any kindput in place policies to stop using fossil fuels of all kinds as fast as possible, prioritizing coal. Understand that there are a number of reasons for reducing our use of fossil fuels. Climate change is controversial - the others are much less so. The Earth has only finite resources - including oil, natural gas, and coal. At some point these will run out. Yes - we almost certainly have greater reserves than we think - but the Earth is a finite size and even if it’s made 100% of fossil fuels (which, of course, is not the case) there will come the day when the last bit is gone. So even if you believe that CO2 has nothing to do with global warming, one would hope that you agree we should be able to continue making energy as long as we have a civilization on Earth. Which means either finding a source of hydrocarbons “out there” somewhere, or finding alternatives to burning things for power.Hydrocarbons are complex and valuable molecules that we use for a number of purposes that include plastics, pharmaceuticals, fertilizers, and more. Does it make sense to burn them, making them unavailable for any other use? And - yes - I know that we can make much of this without hydrocarbons. But these alternate methods tend to require more energy and they can be less efficient.Increasing CO2 concentrations in the atmosphere lead to increasing CO2 concentrations in oceans and lakes. This makes life difficult for the organisms that can only exist in a relatively narrow pH range - such as a lot of the critters that make up the base of the food chain. And - yes - I know that CO2 levels (and oceanic pH) have been far higher (and lower) at times in the past - but the changes took place gradually enough that animals and plants could adapt. That is not the case now.And now one style point. Burning things for energy is so…Ice Age…of us. It ought to be kind of embarrassing that, in over 200,000 years, we’re still burning things to keep warm.It doesn’t matter if climate change is real or not - none of these arguments has anything to do with climate change. If it’s not real - we still need to transition to a source of energy that won’t run out in a century or less, we still have better uses for the chemicals than burning them, and we are still acidifying the oceans. And if it is real - we’ll be helping to combat it as well. So - understand that there are very real reasons that have nothing to do with climate change, that call for us to take the very actions that will help to combat it if it is real.

Climate change is due mostly to the release of greenhouse gases which in turn are due to us humans: burning fossil fuels for energy, large farming operations, pollution in oceans killing plankton that absorb Co2, clearing forests that also absorb CO2, etc, etc. So the best way to mitigate climate change is to mitigate the release of GHGs. So there are PLENTY of viable options to mitigate these changes. The easiest, fastest and least expensive (in my opinion are): Plant trees. Trees absorb CO2 in vast amounts. They can also be raised to provide fuel for electricity generation and converted to energy via gasification (vs incineration) which retains most of the carbon as a solid vs emitting it as CO2. The harvesting can be done once the trees are mature, at which time their annual CO2 absorption levels off and before they die and decompose (which would release much of the stored carbon as CO2 and CH4) … or before the forests are lost to fire, which also would release all the stored carbon at once. A recent study calculated that planting a trillion trees around the world would stall the buildup of GHGs, at least temporarily.Plant fuel crops for anaerobic digestion. AD creates natural gas from plant matter using bacteria. The gas can be used to generate heat and electricity and the carbon (similar to above) is left behind as a solid. The same AD can be used to convert animal waste and septic waste to energy, both of which contribute large amounts of methane to the air. Methane is a more potent GHG than CO2!Convert Municipal Solid Waste into energy. Food can be converted via AD and plastics, wood, textiles, paper, cardboard, etc can be converted using gasification. This would save an equivalent amount of fossil fuels being used. In the case of food waste, AD can be done fairly inexpensively at home. The gas won't likely be enough to run a generator, but could easily be used to augment the heat in your water tank or forced air furnace.Add solar panels (PV) everywhere practical. The cost of solar energy has gotten very low. It's almost as practical to use solar (at least during daylight hours) as it is to use fossil fuels. In many places it is actually more cost-efficient to do so.Use solar heat to heat our homes and water. Vacuum tubes are quite efficient and can raise the temperature of water by 10 to 20 degrees quite easily, if not all the way to 120F. It uses less energy to raise the water temperature from 70F than it does from 50F.Use ground source heat pumps to heat and cool. Again, even if they are not used to do the entire job, just adjusting heat (or cooling) levels by even 5F degrees using “free” energy in the ground can have a significant effect on the use of other costly energy sources.

Q: What do you think is the best solution to stop climate change? We can't "stop" climate change. It is a natural process over which humanity has no control. What we can do is try and not contribute to the changing climate as much as we do by burning less carbon fuel. The climate would continue to change (i.e., continue to warm), just not as quickly. At least, that's what we're being told. In order to do that, we need to change how we generate electricity. Other sources of CO2 (transportation, construction, and some manufacturing) are decades away from reducing their carbon output. When (if) they ever do, they'll just shift the burden onto the electric grid. That's where we need to focus our efforts. The only way to do that is to shift to nuclear power. Wind, solar, and hydro can be in the mix, but they cannot scale to the levels needed to address the issue. And, apart from hydro, they also emit CO2. Nuclear energy has to be at the forefront of the effort. This comes with risks, however. There are issues of nuclear waste, the potential for releasing radioactive material into the environment, and proliferation concerns. All legitimate, of course, and this is why climate change advocates reject the technology. Understandable. However, they also tell us the climate change is the "greatest existential threat to the planet." President Obama told us in a State of the Union address "No challenge - no challenge - poses a greater threat to future generations than climate change." It's a greater threat than war, disease, famine, pestilence, poverty, or anything else threatening humanity. That's pretty serious if you ask me. I've seen articles back in the day saying climate change "will" (not "could," not "might" - "will") lead to the end of civilization, whatever that means. Ocasio-Cortez tells us we have just over 10 years before we're irreversibly doomed. So, which is it? Is climate change really that big of a deal? If so, then why haven't we embarked on an ambitious plan to replace our existing coal/oil/gas electrical generation plants with nuclear plants? We're at least a decade behind where we need to be to achieve our goals, and every permit that is denied, or every plant that is shut down, just sets us that much further behind. Or, is nuclear power just too dangerous of a technology? If so, then it appears that the whole climate change narrative is, to say the least, oversold as an emergency. After all, if you have a problem and solution to it, but you won't implement the solution, do you really have a problem? So here are our choices. Go nuclear (and accept the risk that entails), return to a pre-industrial lifestyle (no lights, no phones, no motor cars, not a single luxury), or figure out how to live with the changing climate.

Please be patient when reading this answer as I think to answer it properly first the common assumptions need to be explored. Then I’ll say what, given the little I know in the vast sea of humanity, where this seems to be leading as the best hope for success. The answer a person sees as valid to this varies widely and depends upon underlying assumptions about:- how fast infrastructural change can occur- how fast and widespread behavioural change is possible- whether growth and sustainability are compatible- technology’s ability to help- the power and position taken of vested interests- the speed and impact of attempts at social upheaval(Sadly most of my sources are behind academic paywalls, so I’ve generally left out references.) Tackling these one at a time with as minimal detail as possible: Infrastructural change - Views vary widely on what is a realistic rate of change given existing infrastructure (and what degree of change is necessary) and what the impact will be. To illustrate electric vehicles (EVs) are often touted as a great solution. They are a replacement that works largely within existing infrastructure, unlike light rail which whilst brilliant take years if not decades to plan and implement. (Most seem to place significant infrastructural changes taking 20–30 years.) There are no direct emissions when driving around EVs. But, and this isn’t a small but - how much better an EV is depends upon how the electricity is generated and whether ‘rebound effect’ occurs, plus future approach. In NZ for instance, as electricity is dominated by hydropower and geothermal, (sadly there are still coal powered plants in NZ too), an EV makes a huge difference. So whilst EV is a clear winner and is estimated to roughly halve emissions (Electric Car Myth Buster — Well-To-Wheel Emissions) if we continue with population growth, car ownership growth (China, India), traffic density increase, and the emissions associated with cement for building more roads, it becomes clear that whilst a switch to EV is great, changing the car type alone is not a long-term answer without other changes. Large numbers will also need to change to different modes of transport and infrastructure to support this. This brings me on to behavioural change. Behavioural change - Getting people to change even one thing in the following list is notoriously hard: fly less, switch to non-meat diet, use reusable materials (plastic for instance uses oil in its production and produces plenty of emissions in its lifecycle), buy less, use a car less. [See also infrastructure.] However, once the general populace feels a new social norm is dominant i.e. widely accepted, many people adopt that behaviour through mimicry (e.g. person in front of you doesn’t use a bag for 3 apples so you also don’t), fear of exclusion (e.g. neighbours on both sides go solar so you do too), peer trend (e.g. not taking the lift is is a socially desirable attribute in the workplace) and so on. Getting someone to turn down a large steak because its carbon footprint is large is not easy. For clarity this applies as much to businesses and their behavioural change as much as individuals. The unspoken rules/priorities of a business - profit is the most important outcome, have shifted dramatically in some companies but they are still the minority. Many companies have goals of reducing their emissions per item or per plane seat, which whilst commendable, may not reduce the overall emissions by that company as the number of customers keep growing. This leads me to growth and sustainability. Growth and sustainability - whether growth / degrowth / agrowth is required for a sustainable human existence is debated. (There’s articles that show the tight link between carbon emission reduction and sustainability strategies and philosphy, hence me suddenly switching to talking about sustainability.) Degrowth - a strategy of actively reducing economic growth. Given the years of focus on growth drummed into us this is seen as heretical by believers in capitalism and can prompt accusations of a socialist agenda. It raises though the very realistic issue that economic growth as currently achieved cannot be continued as we’re literally running out of resources (e.g. global soil poverty, deforestation). Others believe agrowth - an approach to economies that ignores whether growth occurs or not (agnostic) is possible. Some believe growth can be ‘decoupled’ from resources - that we will find ways to meet the growth narrative through efficiencies, innovations etc. Whichever of these positions is held changes drastically whether the solution is seen as a fundamental change to society, a social realignment of some degree, or something that human ingenuity can solve. Which leads me onto many people’s faith in technology. Technology - the appeal of thinking we can invent or design our way out of this mess is tangible. Current infrastructures, behaviour, and growth and sustainability are all theoretically possible if a technology comes along that can suck carbon emissions up and do something with them. For those who know the board game monopoly - this is the ‘Get out of jail free’ card. Carbon capture and storage (CCS) is one of the most popular technological angles to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
